Main_Paragraph: Whether explored on its own or as part of a tour taking in a handful of other Southeast Asian countries, Laos is notable for its laid-back charm. Orange-robed monks shuffling along the banks of the Mekong are emblematic of the relaxed pace of life here. Our Laos holidays explore Luang Prabang, the Plain of Jars and Vientiane, and ensure that even when you’re travelling on a budget your trip has a significant benefit to local communities. You’ll stay in guest houses owned by welcoming villagers, eat delicious fresh snacks bought from neighbourhood markets and roadside stalls, and discover Laotian culture from guides brought up in it.
Subtitle: About our Laos holidays
Paragraph1:
Set at the confluence of the Mekong and Nam Khan rivers, rated by UNESCO ‘the best-preserved city in Southeast Asia’, Luang Prabang is considered the cradle of Laotian culture. Notable for its handsomely faded Indochinese architecture and many temples, as well as the daily procession of saffron-robed monks collecting their alms, the city is immensely photogenic. Some of our holidays, such as our specialist photography tours, extend your stay to give you the chance to really see Luang Prabang in focus. When it’s time to move on, from here you can easily reach the Pak Ou Caves, Kuang Si Waterfall, the Plain of Jars and many riverside
wats
(temples). Do skip the rides available at various elephant camps around here, though – the animals are often cruelly treated.
Paragraph2: Vientiane sometimes feels sleepy enough to slip into the Mekong. Laos tours draw to a quiet pause in this low key city, soundtracked by the ever-present rumbling of tuk tuks. The Laotian capital has retained some of the French influences of its brief post World War II occupation, with bakeries selling baguettes and pastries. For many visitors the most fun to be had is simply strolling the riverside to browse quiet local markets and watch monks go about their business. Our holidays also often visit the COPE exhibition centre which soberly documents the Laotian Civil War – entrance fees here help contribute to prosthetic limbs for survivors.
Paragraph3: Pleasant, if nondescript, the town of Phonsavan is notable mainly as the gateway to the Plain of Jars. Shrouded in mystery and carpeted in ordinance dropped by US forces during the Laotian Civil War, this (actually quite hilly) expanse contains thousands of large stone jars of unknown origin. Theories behind them range from fermenting the fearsome Laotian rice wine, to ancient burial rites, to leftovers from the celebrations of a mythical giant king after victory in battle. Our holidays are led by knowledgeable local guides who expound on these ideas while leading you around the few trails that have been safely cleared of unexploded bombs.
Paragraph4: For adventurous families there is much to love here: tubing on the river from backpacker town Vang Vieng; swimming under waterfalls; exploring huge underground cave systems; peaceful cycling trips; and cookery classes led by engaging local chefs sometimes in their own homes, where you can encourage the kids to tackle a little extra spice with every dish. In general, our family holidays in Laos are best suited to kids around age eight and up. There can be long, bumpy road journeys involved and healthcare availability is patchy, our travel team can provide further advice.
Paragraph5: Sharing borders with Vietnam, Cambodia and Thailand, Laos can easily form part of wider Southeast Asia tours. To do so is to explore several very different, but complementary countries. Your trip will take you through the hospitality and hedonism of Thailand, the frenetic cities and peaceful countryside of Vietnam with its grim but fascinating 20th-century history, and Cambodia, with enticing cuisine, welcoming Khmer people and the magnificent Angkor Wat, but you will come away with experiences and memories far beyond a tour itinerary. Our Southeast Asia holidays handle all the tricky logistics of crossing between countries. And they also ensure you’re accompanied by excellent local guides, each of whom has a fascinating perspective to share.
Title6: Types of tours & holidays in Laos
Paragraph6: Whether cruising lazily down the Mekong or bumping along dirt tracks in a tuk tuk, your Laos journey will be all the more enjoyable as part of a small group holiday. It’s not only about the friendly companionship, but about knowing your trip has been curated by people with years of knowledge and experience of travelling in Laos, ensuring you make the most of your time. Not everyone wants to follow a fixed itinerary, however, and if that’s you then consider our tailor made holidays instead. These allow you to craft a Laos itinerary according to your preferred travel dates, and activities. Whichever option you go for, you’ll be staying in welcoming local hotels throughout.

Main_Paragraph: Laos’s weather system is straightforward when compared to the rest of Asia and has two distinct periods – the dry season (Nov to Apr) and the wet season (May-Oct); March-June are the hottest months of the year. When considering the best time to visit Laos, be aware that the northern, central and eastern regions are at a higher altitude than those in the south, where humidity is high and temperatures can be in excess of  35°C in March and April.
when_to_go: When to go to Laos, month by month
when_to_go_html: The rainy season in Laos, which runs from May until late October, makes a real mess of the countrys already difficult dirt roads; although this brings life and lushness to the countryside, youll struggle to get around and see it. March, April, May and June are very hot months with temperatures soaring to 35°C and above, so if you do find yourself in Laos at either end of the hot season, head north for slightly cooler climes. January and February are dry months with comfortable, warm temperatures. It can get quite cold in the north of the country though, so it's best to wrap up during early mornings and late evenings, or if youre travelling on the river. July sees the wet season in full swing and temperatures sitting at around 30°C, except further south in the Bolaven Plateau, where its notably cooler. As it becomes wetter, lush green foliage begins to swathe the landscape in central Laos, while in the south, waterfalls begin to cascade dramatically again. August is the peak of the rainy season and a bit of a washout in Laos, plus travel to remote areas can be troublesome, but by September, the sun starts to shine again  this, combined with glistening waterfalls and leafy, green landscapes helps to make September an optimum month for travellers seeking stunning natural scenery. November and December are all about life on the river  river levels are at their highest and conditions are dry and warm throughout the country making it an ideal time to journey along the mighty Mekong, taking in all of the incredible flora and fauna that line its banks.

paragraph2: A real benefit to visiting Laos in the dry season is Pi Mai, the Laos New Year celebrations that happen in April. Its a huge week long party in the street celebrating the end of the dry season and the start of the rainy season. Everyone has a water gun, so theres no hiding behind anyone to escape from getting wet; theyll definitely have a water gun and will soak you through while belly laughing. A 90-year-old grandma in the street  dont trust her.
